revision.text:
{{Project Catholicism|class=B|importance=mid}}
==Links== Obviously this should link to an article on the Liturgy of the Hours, but I don't know if one exists (or if not, what to call one).
[[Liturgy of the Hours]] works :) [[User:Secretlondon|Secretlondon]] 23:58, Dec 21, 2003 (UTC)
: Doh, I'm an idiot. :)
==Comment== "In the early days of Christian worship, when Jewish custom was followed, the Bible furnished all that was thought necessary, containing as it did the books from which the lessons were read and the psalms that were recited."
If it means the Tanakh or Old Testament, then I guess this is correct. Otherwise this might violate NPOV and suggest "Sola Scriptura" and is not factually true as the New Testament Canon at that time did not exist. --[[Special:Contributions/208.49.131.4|208.49.131.4]] ([[User talk:208.49.131.4|talk]]) 15:23, 18 March 2008 (UTC)
Under the section "The Proprium Sanctorum", the last sentence reads "Covering a great stretch of time and space, they do for the worshipper in the field of church history what the Scripture readings do in that of biblical history."
I can't understand this sentence. I think it needs to be clearer. [[User:Hlaufman|Harrington]] ([[User talk:Hlaufman|talk]]) 22:34, 19 May 2009 (UTC)
==Gregory DiPippo's Historical Overview== Is available on the web at [http://www.newliturgicalmovement.org/search/label/Compendium%20of%20the%20Reforms%20of%20the%20Roman%20Breviary%201568-1961 this site]. [[User:Rwflammang|Rwflammang]] ([[User talk:Rwflammang|talk]]) 09:29, 7 November 2011 (UTC)
